case_name: Hindu undivided family v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 308 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 308 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 115 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 115 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant is a Hindu undivided family carrying on business as dealer in iron scrap and hardware.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Hindu undivided family and carries on business as a dealer in iron scrap and hardware.

facts.text: Hoare Miller and Company Ltd. owned a jute pressing factory on land belonging to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Hoare Miller and Company Ltd.--hereinafter called the Company --were owners of a jute pressing factory installed on a piece of land belonging to the Company.

facts.text: On January 21, 1941, the Company leased the jute pressing factory and machinery to Ramnath Bajoria for ten months commencing from January 10, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: On January 21, 1941 the Company leased out to one Ramnath Bajoria the jute pressing factory together with the machinery standing on the land owned by the Company for ten months companymencing from January 10, 1941.

facts.text: Ramnath Bajoria failed to vacate after lease expiry, Company instituted ejectment suit.

anchor.surface_text: Ramnath Bajoria failed to vacate and deliver up possession of the premises demised to him, after the expiry of the period of the lease, and the Company instituted a suit in ejectment against him.

facts.text: On October 31, 1942, appellant agreed to purchase all rights of Company in factory and premises for Rs. 2,45,000.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated October 31, 1942 the appellant agreed to purchase all the rights of the Company in the factory and the appurtenant premises for Rs. 2,45,000.

facts.text: On November 14, 1942, Company delivered possession to appellant except leased factory.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1942 the Company delivered to the appellant possession of the property agreed to be sold, save and except the factory demised under the lease to Ramnath Bajoria and the machinery included in the lease.

facts.text: On February 26, 1943, Company executed conveyance to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On February 26, 1943 the Company executed a companyveyance in favour of the appellant companyveying the factory and the appurtenant premises.

facts.text: On June 12, 1943, appellant agreed to sell property to Ranada Prasad Saha for Rs. 4,73,364/3/6 free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: On June 12, 1943 the appellant agreed to sell to one Ranada Prasad Saha the property purchased from the Company for Rs. 4,73,364/3/6 free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: On August 10, 1943, appellant substituted as plaintiff in suit against Ramnath Bajoria and obtained possession.

anchor.surface_text: On August 10. 1943 the appellant was substituted as a plaintiff in the suit filed by the Company against Ramnath Bajoria, and obtained possession of the factory premises.

facts.text: On September 30, 1943, appellant conveyed property to Ranada Prasad Saha and delivered possession.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of companyveyance dated September 30, 1943 the appellant companyveyed to Ranada Prasad Saha the factory and the appurtenant premises and delivered possession thereof.

facts.text: Property sold described in three Schedules: Sch I (Press House etc on Company land), Sch II (leasehold land with warehouse), Sch III (licensee land with two warehouses).

anchor.surface_text: In the deed of companyveyance the property sold was described in three separate Schedules. Schedule I, Press House, office, residential buildings and three warehouses on land owned by the Company Schedule 11 leasehold land together with a warehouse known as Kalibari godown Schedule II1 two warehouses on land held as licensee by the Company from the Government of West Bengal.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed Rs. 2,24,864 as profit in appellant's hands.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer. District Ii 1 , CAlcutta. brought to tax in the hands of the appellant Rs. 2,24,864 bring the profit arising out of the sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha.

facts.text: Tribunal partially modified ITO order, reduced total income by Rs. 7,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal partially modified the order and reduced the total income by Rs. 7,000.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: whether surplus of Rs. 2,35,211 was adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then drew up a statement of case and referred the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the surplus of Rs. 2,35,211 received by the assessee as a result of the sale of the jute press referred to in the Appellate order arose out of an adventure in the nature of trade and was therefore rightly assessed to tax?

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appellant never carried on business in jute or pressing jute.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was carrying on business in iron scrap and hardware and never carried on any business in jute or in pressing jute.

facts.text: At material time, appellant had closed its iron scrap business due to abnormal conditions in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time when the purchase of the Jute Press was made, the appellant had, because of abnormal companyditions prevailing in the town of Calcutta, closed its business in iron scrap and hardware.

facts.text: Appellant purchased subject to litigation, effected repairs, kept factory running but no attempt to start jute pressing business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant purchased the jute press and the premises appurtenant thereto subject to litigation pending in the High Court, effected certain repairs and kept the factory in running companydition, but made numberattempt to start or organise the business of pressing jute,

facts.text: Appellant's plea that unable to secure labour was not true.

anchor.surface_text: and his plea that he was number able to secure labour for working the press was number true.

facts.text: Soon after purchase, appellant received and accepted offer from Ranada Prasad Saha.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after he bought the factory, the appellant received an offer from Ranada Prasad Saha to buy the factory and he immediately accepted the offer to sell it to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds transaction was isolated venture not related to appellant's business.

anchor.surface_text: Purchase of the property by the appellant was an isolated transaction number related to the business of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant put factory in working condition but did not organize jute pressing business.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the appellant had put the factory in a working companydition, but had number organized a jute pressing business, had number obtained a licence for working the factory, had number attempted to secure orders for pressing jute, and had number employed labourers,

facts.text: Appellant's claim of inability to secure labourers not accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claim that it was number s9 done because the appellant companyld number secure labourers has number been accepted.

facts.text: No evidence appellant demolished warehouses and sold as scrap beyond materials delivered in sale deed.

anchor.surface_text: The only fact which may be taken to be established is that a warehouse or warehouses were demolished by the appellant and the materials were sold as part of the property sold under the deed dated September 30. 2943.

facts.text: Ranada Prasad Saha approached Company first, then appellant after learning it was sold to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Ranada Prasad Saha on companying to learn that the factory was for sale approached the Company after the sale deed was executed in favour of the appellant and he was informed that it had already been sold to the appellant. Thereafter Saha companytacted the appellant and agreed to purchase the property.

facts.text: Supreme Court discharges High Court's affirmative answer, records negative answer.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore discharge the answer given by the High Court in respect of the question submitted by the Tribunal and record a negative answer. The appeal is allowed.

facts.text: At material time, capital gains were not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, capital gains were number taxable, and the only question failing to be determined is whether profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was taxabIe under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Transaction was isolated venture on common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the transaction of purchase and sale of the factory and appurtenant premises was an isolated venture.

arguments.claim: after purchasing the factory and the appurtenant premises the appellant demolished certain godowns in Sch. III land and sold the material as scrap. This was a venture similar to the normal business of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that after purchasing the factory and the appurtenant premises the appellant demolished certain godowns in Sch. III land and sold the material as scrap. This, it was claimed, was--if not part of the business--a venture similar to the normal business of the appellant.

arguments.claim: a profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, for, an accretion to capital does not become taxable income, merely because an asset was acquired in the expectation that it may be sold at profit

anchor.surface_text: It may be emphasized from an analysis of these cases that a profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, for, an accretion to capital does not become taxable income, merely because an asset was acquired in the expectation that it may be sold at profit.

arguments.claim: The Tribunal and the High Court were in error in holding that the right of the Company was not sold to the appellant in the lands in Sch. II and Sch. III properties

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court were, in our judgment, in error in holding that the right of the Company was not sold to the appellant in the lands in Sch. II and Sch. III properties.

arguments.court_reasoning: Recitals in sale deeds indicate full rights transferred

anchor.surface_text: The property purchased was not such that an inference that a venture in the nature of trade must have been intended by the appellant in respect thereof may be raised.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was not right in holding that the surplus of Rs. 2,35,211 received by the assessee as a result of the sale of the jute press arose out of an adventure in the nature of trade and was therefore not rightly assessed to tax.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore discharge the answer given by the High Court in respect of the question submitted by the Tribunal and record a negative answer. The appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test from precedents; transaction isolated, unrelated to assessee's business in scrap/hardware, no commodity alteration, no business organization, quick resale on unsolicited offer, profit motive insufficient alone.

holdings.text: Profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was not taxable under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, capital gains were not taxable, and the only question failing to be determined is whether profit made by the appellant by sale of the property to Ranada Prasad Saha was taxable under s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since not an adventure in nature of trade and capital gains not taxable, falls outside s.10 taxation of business profits.

holdings.text: The facts do not make out that the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: Do these facts make out the case that the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade? It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue failed to establish indicia of trade despite burden; no relation to business, no repairs/treatment suggesting trade, no magnitude or dealings indicating venture.

holdings.text: The question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: It has consistently been held by this Court that the question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact see G. Venkataswami Naidu & Co. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following consistent Supreme Court precedents like Venkataswami Naidu; requires legal elements of trade before factual conclusion.

holdings.text: It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and liable to be taxed as income.

anchor.surface_text: It is for the revenue to establish that the profit earned in a transaction is within the taxing provision and is on that account liable to be taxed as income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard burden of proof in tax cases; revenue must prove adventure in trade.

holdings.text: A profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, as accretion to capital does not become taxable income merely because asset acquired in expectation of profit.

anchor.surface_text: It may be emphasized from an analysis of these cases that a profit motive in entering a transaction is not decisive, for, an accretion to capital does not become taxable income, merely because an asset was acquired in the expectation that it may be sold at profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawn from analysis of precedents; distinguishes capital accretion from taxable business profit.

holdings.text: The Tribunal and the High Court were in error in holding that the right of the Company was not sold to the appellant in the lands in Sch. II and Sch. III properties.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court were, in our judgment, in error in holding that the right of the Company was not sold to the appellant in the lands in Sch. II and Sch. III properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recitals in conveyance deeds indicate full rights transferred without reservation.

holdings.text: Purchase of the property by the appellant was an isolated transaction not related to the business of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Purchase of the property by the appellant was an isolated transaction not related to the business of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee in scrap/hardware, not jute; closed business due to conditions; no link.

holdings.text: Barring the expectation of profit and realization of profit by sale of the property, there is no evidence bearing on the intention with which the property was purchased.

anchor.surface_text: Barring the expectation of profit and realization of profit by sale of the property, there is no evidence bearing on the intention with which the property was purchased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of evidence on trade intent beyond resale profit.

holdings.text: From the circumstance of demolition and sale of warehouse materials as part of the property, an inference that the entire property was purchased with intent to demolish and dispose of as scrap cannot be raised.

anchor.surface_text: The only fact which may be taken to be established is that a warehouse or warehouses were demolished by the appellant and the materials were sold as part of the property sold under the deed dated September 30, 1943.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence on original number of warehouses or serviceability; materials delivered in sale deed.

holdings.text: The property purchased was not such that an inference that a venture in the nature of trade must have been intended by the appellant in respect thereof may be raised.

anchor.surface_text: The property purchased was not such that an inference that a venture in the nature of trade must have been intended by the appellant in respect thereof may be raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jute press capable of own business or letting; previously let by company; no evidence of unlettability.

precedents.cited_proposition: question whether profit in a transaction has arisen out of an adventure in the nature of trade is a mixed question of law and fact; tribunal must consider legal elements associated with concept of trade or business
precedents.cited_holding: the expression adventure in the nature of trade in sub-s. (4) of s. 2 of the Act postulates the existence of certain elements in the adventure which in law would invest it with the character of trade or business
